newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Gas Oil/Jet - Swaps drive jet sharply lower.
newsitem.headline: Asia Gas Oil/Jet - Swaps drive jet sharply lower.

text.p: Singapore jet fuel prices slumped on sharply lower swap offers in the absence of physical trade while gas oil drifted in a directionless market, traders said on Wednesday.
Jet fuel prices collapsed on strong selling in the swaps market where the February regrade (jet fuel/gas oil swaps spread) was offered down to $3.40 per barrel against Tuesday's $4.30/$4.70.
No physical bids or offers were heard on Wednesday.
On Tuesday, a bid was heard for 100,000 barrels at $30.10 a barrel for Feb 26-Mar 2 lifting fob, about 90 cents below last Thursday's buying number.
Traders said the lower swaps prices were indicative of the bearish market, where most consumers have covered their winter requirement.
Jet fuel supplies are tight in Singapore due to earlier committments but because there is no fresh buying the market was sold down, traders said.
Japan earlier bought two cargoes from South Korea at around $2.20 per barrel over Singapore spot quotes on a cost-and-freight basis, in line with recent trades.
Gas oil drifted sideways as the market was weighed down by offers from one local trader despite indications of fresh demand from India and China.
The local trader has sold a total of seven 150,000-190,000-barrel cargoes since mid-January.
The trader had earlier imported 440,000-tonnes of gas oil from the Middle East for sale to China but Chinese buying has ground to a halt since mid-January.
"We bought the cargoes to sell to China but now we are stuck. We still have cargoes to sell," the trader said.
As a result of the traders' predicament, most players said it would be difficult for gas oil to rise substantially.

The Singapore gas oil market was boosted by news of a 50,000-tonne sale recently to a trader to cover committments to India--the first time in months that cargoes from Singapore were used to cover Indian Oil Corp's (IOC) monthly requirement.
Also China had put out feelers to buy cargoes for late February and March arrival.
The trader today offered a 150,000-barrel cargo at $25.30 per barrel for Feb 27-Mar 3 lifting fob, 20 cents above Tuesday's traded level.
Gas oil swaps were steady throughout the day at $25.30/$25.50 per barrel, largely unchanged from Tuesday's $25.45/$25.55.
(Prices in dollars per barrel)
MTH FOB SIN BUY/SELL PREV BUY/SELL
FEB JET KEROSENE/KERO 29.50/30.00 30.50/30.70
FEB JET/GAS OIL SWAPS 3.00/3.40 4.30/4.70
-- Singapore Newsroom (+65-870 3093)
